description: Final semester of a two year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengineering and Bioengineering Science courses. It is required for only BSE majors. It is intended for the spring semester of the Junior year.
name: BIOENGINEERING LAB III

values.comments: This course is the final semester of a two year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengineering and Bioengineering Science courses. The course structure is very similar to the other bioengineering labs.  Most of the students praised the labs, saying that it was the “best lab course so far.” Generally, students felt that the content of the lab course was “very well designed” and “gives a sense of completion.” Some students enjoyed the lectures before the labs and found them “informative,” while others found them “redundant” and a bit “punishing for the people who read the manuals.”  Professor Rizk was praised for his teaching style. He was described as “spectacular” and “very friendly.” Overall, he was very informative in his lectures and received good reviews from almost everyone.  The course was described to be “sufficiently difficult.” In addition, a few students found the amount of programming required “unreasonable,” but they were in the minority. This course is highly recommended for Bioengineering majors.

BE 310 is the fourth semester-long lab in a two year sequence. Designed to integrate real-world experiences into Bioengineering and various Bioengineering Science courses, this course is meant to be taken second semester Junior year. This lab is only required for Bioengineering majors pursuing a BSE.  Students generally found the course to be a “great class” with “interesting labs.” One student went as far as to say that it was “one of, if not my favorite of the 3 current BE labs.” Some students felt that the graded lab reports could have been returned earlier, although they also noted gratitude for extensions received around Penn traditions (i.e. Spring Fling, Hey Day).  Professor Salinas was generally highly regarded by her students. Students reported that she was nice and that her teaching was clear and straightforward. Professor Salinas was “refreshingly helpful during the actual lab time” and one student even reported that she was “one of the best professors [he’s] had to date.” Some students did find, however, that her grading seemed “a bit arbitrary” at times, and that she focused more on “grammar, syntax, [and] formatting” than on the “content of the labs.”  This class consists of mostly, if not all, junior Bioengineering majors. The lab is meant as the third and final lab in a sequence of labs begun in the fall of sophomore year. Students reported that there was a “good amount of work” but that it was not excessive.
